metadata.description: Comprehensive test suite for MRI Report Parser - targeting 80%+ coverage
metadata.notes: Combines real Radiopaedia cases, edge cases, and literature-based synthetic cases

test_cases.title: Intersphincteric fistula with abscess
test_cases.report_text: linear fistulous tract is seen oriented vertically, passing through the left side of the inter-sphincteric plane, starting superiorly from the level of the dentate line where it is seen abutting the internal sphincter at 1-2 o'clock position, and extending inferiorly to open into a marginally enhancing inflammatory fluid collection (abscess) the external sphincter is intact no definite side branches

test_cases.title: Grade 4 transsphincteric fistula with abscess
test_cases.report_text: A relatively thick-walled fistulous track traverses both internal and external anal sphincters piercing and penetrating through the left ischioanal fossa. Its internal opening pierces the anal canal anteriorly near 1 o'clock where a fairly defined restricted collection / abscess formation is seen. The collection measures 1.8 x 1.5 cm. It shows restricted diffusion. Then the thick track protrudes and proceeds to make a hook down anteriorly along the ischioanal fossa for a length of about 9.7 cm. Its external opening being near 3 o'clock. The track has a thick enhanced wall and high signal intensity enhanced content.

test_cases.title: Simple transsphincteric fistula - active
test_cases.report_text: In the perianal region, a tortuous-looking fistulous tract is identified at the 12 o'clock position, with hyperintense behavior on T2. It runs caudally between the internal and external anal sphincters towards the ischioanal fossa, without the presence of a collection. There is a wrap-around artefact on the axial T2 HASTE fat sat and axial T1 VIBE sequences.

test_cases.title: Simple intersphincteric - healing
test_cases.report_text: There is a simple intersphincteric perianal fistula. Internal opening: 10 o'clock. Shape: linear. Secondary tract or abscess: no. External opening: right side of the gluteal cleft. Evidence of any disease: no. There is no fluid in the tract but there is enhancement, the interpretation is that there is granulation tissue but no pus.

test_cases.title: Normal - no fistula
test_cases.report_text: No perianal fistula, sinus tract or collection. No subcutaneous edema. The internal and external sphincters and the pelvic floor are unremarkable. No gross adnexal mass. No pelvic free fluid. Conclusion: No abnormality demonstrated.
test_cases.notes: Normal study - used as negative control

test_cases.title: Intersphincteric with horseshoe abscess
test_cases.report_text: Posterior midline fistulous tract seen in the 6 o'clock position with a peripherally enhancing horseshoe abscess measuring 17 x 30 x 44 mm in the intersphincteric space.

test_cases.title: Intersphincteric with thigh extension
test_cases.report_text: A long fistulous tract at the right side of the perianal region piercing the internal sphincter at 7 o'clock with the surrounding inflammatory region. The tract shows mild restriction on diffusion-weighted imaging. No abscess formation or side branches. Features are of intersphincteric fistula with the track extending into the right medial thigh soft tissues.

test_cases.title: Superficial fistula to scrotum
test_cases.report_text: Fistulous tract from the low anterior anal canal just above the anal verge (well below puborectalis) to the base of the scrotum. There is associated skin thickening and enhancement due to inflammation, but no distinct abscess.

test_cases.title: Crohn's - no perianal fistula
test_cases.report_text: Penetrating disease sinus tracts in the ileum in the mid and left lower abdomen. No complex fistulas, abscess or an inflammatory mass. An additional pelvic MRI confirmed the left sacroiliitis but did not show any significant perianal complications such as a fistula or an abscess.

test_cases.title: Fistulogram - incomplete MRI info
test_cases.report_text: Dye fistulogram - low fistula dye spilling in the anal canal and rectum. Injection of contrast via the external opening showed opacification of the right perianal fistula which travels superiorly. The tract communicates with the anal canal and rectum.

test_cases.title: High transsphincteric with setons
test_cases.report_text: High transphincteric perianal fistula at the 6 o'clock position with seton in situ. The fistula extends from the anal canal through both sphincters into the ischioanal fossa. There is mild surrounding T2 hyperintensity indicating residual inflammation. A second seton is noted in a smaller branch tract at the 5 o'clock position. No discrete abscess collection. Post-treatment changes noted.

test_cases.title: Non-perianal fistula (vesicovaginal)
test_cases.report_text: A vesicovaginal fistula is identified with abnormal communication between the bladder and vaginal vault. The fistulous tract shows enhancement. No perianal involvement. The anal sphincter complex appears normal.
test_cases.notes: Non-perianal fistula - tests ability to distinguish fistula types

test_cases.title: Extrasphincteric fistula with gluteal extension
test_cases.report_text: MRI demonstrates an extrasphincteric fistula originating above the levator plate and extending into the left gluteal region. The tract shows marked T2 hyperintensity with extensive surrounding soft tissue edema. A 3.2 x 2.8 cm rim-enhancing collection is present in the gluteal musculature consistent with abscess. The rectal wall shows focal inflammatory changes at the site of the internal opening. No horseshoe extension identified.

test_cases.title: Complex multi-tract Crohn's fistula
test_cases.report_text: Extensive perianal fistulizing Crohn's disease. Multiple complex fistulous tracts identified: (1) High transsphincteric fistula at 11 o'clock with horseshoe extension crossing the posterior midline, (2) Intersphincteric fistula at 5 o'clock. Both tracts demonstrate marked T2 hyperintensity and avid post-contrast enhancement. Large inflammatory mass measuring 4.2 x 3.1 cm in the right ischioanal fossa with central necrosis. Moderate rectal wall thickening with mucosal hyperenhancement. Findings indicate severe active perianal Crohn's disease.

test_cases.title: Healed fistula - fibrotic tract
test_cases.report_text: Follow-up MRI for treated perianal fistula. Previously identified transsphincteric tract now shows marked decrease in T2 signal intensity. The tract appears as a thin linear hypointense structure without surrounding edema. No abscess or collection. No residual enhancement on post-contrast sequences. Findings consistent with fibrotic healing. The rectal wall is normal in appearance.

test_cases.title: Complete fistula resolution
test_cases.report_text: Previously noted transsphincteric fistula now shows complete resolution. No residual tract identified. No enhancement. Scar tissue only. No T2 hyperintensity. The sphincter complex is intact. No perianal collection or abscess. Findings consistent with complete healing.

test_cases.title: Multiple separate fistulas - moderate
test_cases.report_text: Three distinct perianal fistula tracts identified. First: intersphincteric fistula at 3 o'clock position with internal opening at dentate line. Second: transsphincteric fistula at 7 o'clock position, separate internal opening, extending into left ischioanal fossa. Third: superficial fistula at 11 o'clock position with separate internal opening. No connection between the three tracts. All show mild T2 hyperintensity. No abscess or collection.

test_cases.title: Abscess without definite fistula tract
test_cases.report_text: 3.2 cm rim-enhancing perirectal abscess at 5 o'clock position. The collection shows T2 hyperintensity centrally with peripheral enhancement. No definite fistula tract identified connecting to the anal canal. No internal opening visualized. Differential includes cryptoglandular abscess versus early fistula formation. Recommend drainage and follow-up MRI.

test_cases.title: Post-fistulotomy follow-up - healed
test_cases.report_text: Status post fistulotomy 6 months prior for right-sided transsphincteric fistula. Surgical site shows expected post-operative changes with granulation tissue. No recurrent fistula tract identified. No T2 hyperintensity. No collection or abscess. The internal and external sphincters show post-surgical changes but are intact. No active inflammation. Findings consistent with successful surgical treatment.

test_cases.title: Equivocal findings with motion artifact
test_cases.report_text: Some changes noted in the perirectal region at 6 o'clock. Possible tract versus post-inflammatory changes - findings are equivocal. Limited evaluation due to motion artifact. No definite abscess, though small fluid signal cannot be excluded. Clinical correlation recommended. Consider repeat MRI with sedation if symptoms persist.
test_cases.notes: Parser should flag LOW CONFIDENCE due to uncertainty

test_cases.title: Complex horseshoe fistula
test_cases.report_text: Complex horseshoe fistula with posterior midline origin at 6 o'clock position. The primary tract extends through the intersphincteric space bilaterally, forming a horseshoe configuration crossing the posterior midline. Secondary tracts extend into both ischioanal fossae. Multiple small collections measuring up to 1.5 cm along the tract course. Marked T2 hyperintensity throughout. No supralevator extension. Rectal wall appears normal.

test_cases.title: Pediatric Crohn's - simple fistula
test_cases.report_text: In this 12-year-old with known Crohn's disease, there is a simple intersphincteric fistula at the 6 o'clock position. The tract is linear, measuring 2.1 cm in length. Mild T2 hyperintensity is present consistent with mild inflammation. No abscess or collection. No extension beyond the intersphincteric space. Sphincter complex intact. Findings discussed with pediatric GI team.

test_cases.title: Mixed healed and active fistulas
test_cases.report_text: Two perianal fistulas identified. Right-sided transsphincteric tract at 3 o'clock shows low T2 signal, no enhancement, thin fibrotic appearance - consistent with healed fistula. Left-sided intersphincteric tract at 9 o'clock demonstrates marked T2 hyperintensity, avid enhancement, and a small 0.8 cm associated abscess - active inflammatory fistula. Overall pattern suggests mixed disease activity with one healed and one active fistula.

test_cases.title: Maximum severity - all features present
test_cases.report_text: Severe perianal Crohn's disease with extensive findings. Large 4 cm presacral abscess with marked T2 hyperintensity. Complex branching fistula system with horseshoe configuration and supralevator extension. Three branches identified: high transsphincteric at 6 o'clock, intersphincteric at 3 o'clock, and extrasphincteric at 9 o'clock. Marked rectal wall thickening with mucosal hyperenhancement. Inflammatory mass in the right ischioanal fossa measuring 3.5 x 2.8 cm with central necrosis. Recommend urgent surgical consultation.

test_cases.title: Completely normal study
test_cases.report_text: MRI pelvis performed for evaluation of perianal symptoms. Study is unremarkable. No fistula tract identified. No abscess or collection. No inflammatory changes in the perianal region. Normal rectal wall without thickening or enhancement abnormality. Internal and external sphincters appear normal. No perirectal abnormality. No pelvic lymphadenopathy. Conclusion: Normal MRI pelvis, no evidence of perianal fistula or inflammation.

test_cases.title: Early small new fistula
test_cases.report_text: First MRI for new perianal symptoms. No prior imaging available for comparison. Small 1.5 cm intersphincteric fistula tract identified at 6 o'clock position with mild T2 hyperintensity and subtle enhancement. No abscess or collection. No extension beyond intersphincteric space. Sphincter complex intact. Findings consistent with early perianal fistulizing disease.

test_cases.title: Healed transsphincteric fistula
test_cases.report_text: Follow-up MRI in patient with known Crohn's disease, 8 months post biologic therapy initiation. Previously documented high transsphincteric fistula at 5 o'clock position now shows complete resolution of active inflammation. The tract is barely perceptible as a thin hypointense linear structure without surrounding edema. No T2 hyperintensity within or around the tract. No residual enhancement on post-contrast sequences. External and internal sphincters appear intact without disruption. No collections or abscesses. Rectal wall is normal thickness without edema. Clinical remission confirmed.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on Van Assche et al. healing patterns post anti-TNF therapy (AJG 2003)

test_cases.title: Resolved transsphincteric post-seton removal
test_cases.report_text: Post-treatment MRI 6 months after seton removal. Previous transsphincteric fistula at 7 o'clock is no longer visualized as an active tract. Residual fibrotic strand noted in the expected tract location with low T2 signal intensity. No fluid within the tract. Complete absence of perilesional inflammation. Sphincter muscles show expected post-treatment changes but maintain normal morphology. No perianal collections. Normal rectal mucosa. Findings consistent with fistula healing in remission.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on Beets-Tan et al. post-treatment imaging patterns (Radiology 2001)

test_cases.title: Quiescent transsphincteric on maintenance therapy
test_cases.report_text: Surveillance MRI in patient on ustekinumab maintenance. Known transsphincteric fistula at 6 o'clock position demonstrates imaging remission. The tract appears as a fibrotic remnant without active inflammation. No T2 hyperintense signal. No enhancement post-gadolinium. No perilesional edema or fat stranding. Both sphincter muscles intact. No collections identified. Clinical and radiological remission achieved. Continue current therapy.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on ADMIRE-CD long-term follow-up data (Lancet 2016)

test_cases.title: Healed complex fistula - post biologic
test_cases.report_text: Follow-up MRI 12 months post initiation of vedolizumab. Previously identified complex branching fistula with multiple secondary tracts now shows complete resolution of active disease. Primary and secondary tracts appear completely fibrosed with low signal on all sequences. No residual T2 hyperintensity. No enhancing tissue within any tract remnants. The previously seen lateral extensions have resolved to thin fibrous strands. No abscess. No inflammatory mass. The sphincter complex shows mild post-inflammatory architectural changes but is functionally intact. Imaging consistent with radiological remission of complex perianal disease.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on GETAID-OBSERV healing patterns (Inflamm Bowel Dis 2020)

test_cases.title: Resolved branching fistula - long-term follow-up
test_cases.report_text: Two-year follow-up MRI after EUA with seton placement and subsequent biologic therapy. Previously complex fistula system with Y-shaped branching pattern now demonstrates complete healing. All tracts show fibrotic transformation without residual inflammation. T2 signal within tracts is low, isointense to muscle. No contrast enhancement identified in any tract remnant. No perianal fluid collections. The external sphincter shows focal scarring at 4 o'clock but maintains continuity. No active disease. Patient in sustained clinical and radiological remission.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on Geltzeiler et al. surgical plus biologic outcomes (DCR 2018)

test_cases.title: Early branching fistula - low inflammation
test_cases.report_text: MRI pelvis demonstrates an intersphincteric fistula with early secondary tract formation. Primary tract originates at 6 o'clock with minimal T2 hyperintensity. A small secondary branch extends laterally toward 4 o'clock, measuring 1.5 cm in length. The branching is limited and well-defined. No significant inflammation of surrounding tissues. No abscess formation. External sphincter intact. Minimal rectal wall involvement limited to the internal opening. Overall findings suggest early or mild disease with developing complexity.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on Parks classification with early branching pattern (BJS 1976)

test_cases.title: Low-grade branching pattern
test_cases.report_text: Perianal MRI shows a primary intersphincteric tract at 7 o'clock with a small secondary extension. The main tract demonstrates only subtle T2 signal abnormality suggesting low-grade inflammation. The secondary branch is short, measuring approximately 1 cm, and extends into the superficial tissues without involving deeper structures. No frank abscess. No supralevator component. Both sphincters are well-preserved. The overall picture is of mild disease with anatomical complexity but limited inflammation.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on St Mark's Hospital classification criteria

test_cases.title: Bifurcating tract with minimal activity
test_cases.report_text: MRI reveals a bifurcating fistula tract pattern. The primary intersphincteric tract at 5 o'clock divides into two terminal branches within the intersphincteric space. Mild T2 hyperintensity is present but limited. No marked inflammatory changes. No perilesional edema. Both branches terminate without external openings visible. No abscess or collection. Sphincter complex is intact. Rectal wall normal. Appearance suggests controlled disease with mild activity despite complex anatomy.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on MAGNIFI-CD mild activity criteria

test_cases.title: Severe scarring from chronic disease
test_cases.report_text: MRI shows extensive fibrotic changes in the perianal region consistent with chronic fistulizing disease. Multiple fibrosed tracts identified with low T2 signal indicating mature scar tissue. Significant distortion of the sphincter complex from prior disease. Dense fibrosis extending into ischioanal fossa bilaterally. No active inflammation or fluid collections. Rectal wall shows chronic fibrotic thickening. External sphincter is significantly attenuated and scarred. Marked architectural distortion of the anorectal junction. Overall appearance consistent with burned-out severe perianal Crohn's with extensive residual scarring. Despite fibrotic nature, the severity of anatomical damage warrants surgical evaluation.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on MAGNIFI-CD fibrosis scoring and chronic disease patterns

test_cases.title: End-stage fibrotic perianal disease
test_cases.report_text: Extensive fibrotic changes throughout the perianal region in patient with long-standing Crohn's disease. All identified tracts are fibrosed without active inflammation. However, the anatomical damage is severe: significant sphincter disruption bilaterally, extensive scar tissue replacing normal fat planes, severe narrowing of the anal canal from circumferential scarring. Multiple blind-ending fibrotic cords present. The rectal wall shows chronic changes with wall thickening from fibrosis. No abscesses. The fibrosis score is maximal despite absence of active disease. Consideration for defunctioning stoma discussed given severe anatomical compromise.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on severe anatomical damage patterns in burned-out Crohn's

test_cases.title: Severe post-surgical complications
test_cases.report_text: Post-operative MRI following failed fistulotomy procedure. Extensive recurrent disease with multiple new fistula tracts arising from the surgical site. A large 3.5 cm post-operative abscess is present in the left ischioanal fossa with marked surrounding inflammation. The primary tract demonstrates marked T2 hyperintensity with avid enhancement. New extension into the supralevator space not present on prior imaging. The external sphincter shows significant disruption from the prior surgery with subsequent disease recurrence through the surgical defect. The rectal wall is thickened with mucosal hyperenhancement. Findings indicate severe post-surgical recurrence requiring urgent re-intervention.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on recurrence patterns post-fistulotomy (Dis Colon Rectum 2015)

test_cases.title: Failed seton with severe recurrence
test_cases.report_text: MRI following loose seton drainage that has been in place for 18 months without resolution. The seton tract remains actively inflamed with marked T2 hyperintensity. A new secondary tract has developed lateral to the seton track. Large horseshoe collection measuring 4.2 x 2.8 cm extending bilaterally in the posterior intersphincteric space. Marked rectal wall inflammation with proctitis pattern. The external sphincter is significantly damaged with near-complete disruption at the 6 o'clock position. An inflammatory phlegmon is present in the right ischioanal fossa. Findings represent treatment failure with severe disease progression. Recommend escalation of medical therapy and consideration of fecal diversion.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on seton failure patterns and disease progression

test_cases.title: Post-LIFT with minor residual
test_cases.report_text: Follow-up MRI 3 months after LIFT procedure for transsphincteric fistula. Small residual tract identified at the surgical site with mild T2 signal abnormality. The tract does not extend through the sphincter complex. Post-operative granulation tissue present with mild enhancement. No abscess or collection. The sphincters appear intact with expected post-surgical changes at the LIFT site. Minimal perilesional inflammation. Findings suggest partial healing with minor residual disease. Clinical correlation advised.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on LIFT procedure outcomes literature

test_cases.title: Equivocal findings - likely healed
test_cases.report_text: MRI performed for surveillance in patient with history of perianal Crohn's disease currently asymptomatic. Very subtle linear structure identified at 6 o'clock that may represent a fibrosed prior tract or normal anatomical variant. No T2 hyperintensity. No enhancement post-contrast. No surrounding inflammatory changes. No abscess or collection. Sphincter complex normal. Rectal wall unremarkable. If this represents a prior fistula tract, it appears completely healed. Clinical correlation with prior imaging and symptoms recommended. Overall impression favors remission or normal study.
test_cases.notes: Parser should flag MODERATE confidence due to equivocal nature
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on post-treatment surveillance patterns

test_cases.title: Questionable residual - favor healing
test_cases.report_text: Post-treatment MRI in patient on biologic therapy. Questionable residual soft tissue at the site of prior documented intersphincteric fistula. The area shows no definite T2 hyperintensity - findings may represent fibrotic scar versus normal tissue. No definite tract morphology identified. No fluid. No enhancement on post-contrast imaging. No inflammatory changes in the region. Sphincter muscles normal. Imaging findings are equivocal but favor complete healing with possible minimal scar tissue. Patient is clinically in remission.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on imaging assessment of healing uncertainty

test_cases.title: Equivocal but concerning findings
test_cases.report_text: MRI with limited evaluation due to significant motion artifact and patient positioning issues. Despite technical limitations, there appears to be a large collection in the left ischioanal fossa, estimated 3-4 cm, though precise measurement is difficult. Multiple linear structures that likely represent fistula tracts are present but their exact course cannot be confidently traced. There appears to be marked T2 signal abnormality in the region. Possible rectal wall involvement though assessment is limited. The overall impression suggests severe active disease, but findings are equivocal due to image quality. Urgent EUA recommended for definitive assessment.
test_cases.notes: Parser should flag LOW confidence due to image quality issues
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on clinical decision making with suboptimal imaging

test_cases.title: Diagnostic uncertainty - probable severe
test_cases.report_text: Pelvic MRI in patient with acute perianal symptoms. There is definite abnormality in the perianal region with a large collection posteriorly. The collection appears to have marked T2 hyperintensity and shows peripheral enhancement suggestive of abscess. Multiple tract-like structures are present but their classification is uncertain - appearances could represent multiple fistulas or complex single fistula with extensive branching. Differential includes severe Crohn's fistulizing disease versus severe cryptoglandular infection versus atypical presentation of another process. Regardless of etiology, the extent of disease appears severe. Rectal wall appears involved. Urgent surgical consultation recommended.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on diagnostic uncertainty in acute presentations

test_cases.title: Healed horseshoe fistula
test_cases.report_text: Follow-up MRI 12 months after definitive surgical treatment of horseshoe fistula. Previously extensive posterior horseshoe collection now completely resolved. Fibrosed tract remnants visible in deep postanal space with low T2 signal. The bilateral extensions that previously communicated across the posterior midline are now replaced by thin fibrous bands. No residual active inflammation. No fluid collections. Sphincter complex shows post-surgical changes with focal scarring but maintains functional anatomy. Rectal wall normal. Patient clinically in sustained remission. No evidence of recurrent disease.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on post-surgical horseshoe resolution patterns

test_cases.title: Resolved horseshoe post-biologics
test_cases.report_text: Surveillance MRI in patient with history of complex horseshoe fistula, now on combination biologic therapy for 18 months. The previously documented horseshoe configuration fistula has undergone complete healing. Only minimal fibrotic residua remain at the site of prior disease in the deep postanal space. No active tracts identified. No T2 hyperintense signal in the perianal region. No collections. The posterior commissure of the external sphincter shows expected post-inflammatory changes. Clinical and radiological remission confirmed. Continue current medical management.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on biologic-induced remission of complex disease

test_cases.title: Early horseshoe - minimal activity
test_cases.report_text: MRI pelvis reveals an early horseshoe pattern fistula. A posterior midline tract at 6 o'clock shows minimal bilateral extension along the intersphincteric plane. The horseshoe configuration is limited and does not extend into the ischioanal fossae. Mild T2 hyperintensity is present along the tract with subtle enhancement. No discrete abscess or collection. The tracts measure less than 2 cm in total extent bilaterally. Sphincter muscles intact. No rectal wall involvement. Findings represent early or mild horseshoe fistula with limited disease activity.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on early horseshoe patterns before extensive development

test_cases.title: Moderate horseshoe fistula
test_cases.report_text: MRI demonstrates a horseshoe fistula with moderate disease severity. The posterior midline tract extends bilaterally in a classic horseshoe configuration through the intersphincteric space. Moderate T2 hyperintensity throughout the tract. The extensions reach into the lateral aspects of the intersphincteric space but do not extend into the ischioanal fossae. A small 1.2 cm collection is present at the posterior midline origin. No supralevator extension. Sphincter complex shows focal involvement but remains largely intact. Rectal wall is unremarkable. Findings consistent with moderate horseshoe fistula - seton placement recommended.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on mid-severity horseshoe presentations

test_cases.title: Partial horseshoe - controlled disease
test_cases.report_text: Follow-up MRI after 4 months of seton drainage for horseshoe fistula. The disease has improved but remains active at moderate severity. The posterior horseshoe tract still demonstrates moderate T2 hyperintensity. The left arm of the horseshoe has decreased in size significantly. The right arm remains visible but is less prominent than baseline. Small residual collection measuring 0.8 cm at the posterior commissure. No supralevator extension. The setons are visible within the tracts. Sphincter complex preserved. Findings indicate partial response to treatment with moderate residual disease.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on seton response patterns in horseshoe disease

test_cases.title: Healed extrasphincteric fistula
test_cases.report_text: Follow-up MRI 2 years after combined surgical and medical treatment for extrasphincteric fistula. The previously documented suprasphincteric/extrasphincteric tract extending from the rectum above the puborectalis has completely healed. Only a thin fibrotic strand remains at the former tract location with low T2 signal. The supralevator space is clear. No residual active inflammation. No enhancement within the residual tissue. The rectum shows no active disease. Sphincter complex intact. The levator ani muscles are normal. Patient has been in sustained clinical remission. Findings confirm radiological healing of this challenging fistula type.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on rare documented cases of extrasphincteric healing

test_cases.title: Low-grade suprasphincteric fistula
test_cases.report_text: MRI demonstrates a suprasphincteric fistula with low-grade activity. The tract originates high in the rectum, courses above the puborectalis muscle, and descends through the levator plate to reach the perianal skin. Despite its complex course, the tract shows only mild T2 hyperintensity suggesting low inflammatory activity. The tract is thin without significant surrounding edema. No abscess or collection. The supralevator space shows minimal soft tissue change. Rectal wall appears normal at the internal opening site. Findings indicate extrasphincteric anatomy but with mild disease activity - may be suitable for biologic therapy trial.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on Parks Grade 4 low-activity presentations

test_cases.title: Moderate extrasphincteric fistula
test_cases.report_text: MRI pelvis demonstrates an extrasphincteric fistula with moderate disease activity. The tract extends from a rectal opening above the anorectal junction, bypasses the sphincter complex by coursing through the levator ani, and reaches the perianal skin. Moderate T2 hyperintensity within and around the tract. The supralevator portion shows moderate surrounding inflammation. Small collection measuring 1.5 cm in the left supralevator space. No extension into the ischioanal fossa. The sphincter muscles themselves are intact as the tract does not traverse them. Focal rectal wall thickening at the internal opening. Moderate active disease - combined approach recommended.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on Parks Grade 4 moderate presentations

test_cases.title: Pediatric healed fistula
test_cases.report_text: Follow-up MRI in 14-year-old with Crohn's disease after 1 year of infliximab therapy. Previously documented intersphincteric fistula at 5 o'clock now shows complete resolution of active inflammation. The tract appears as a barely visible fibrotic remnant with low T2 signal. No enhancement. No surrounding edema. Sphincter complex intact and age-appropriate. No perianal collections. Rectal wall normal. Clinical and radiological remission confirmed. The pediatric GI team plans to continue maintenance therapy. No current symptoms.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on pediatric Crohn's biologic response patterns

test_cases.title: Adolescent resolved perianal disease
test_cases.report_text: MRI in 16-year-old female with IBD, now on combined immunosuppression. Prior perianal fistula has completely healed. No active tract identified. The area of previous disease shows only minimal fibrotic change. No T2 hyperintensity in the perianal region. No collections. Sphincter muscles normal. The rectum appears healthy. Patient reports no perianal symptoms for 8 months. Imaging confirms sustained remission of perianal Crohn's disease.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on adolescent IBD healing patterns

test_cases.title: Pediatric quiescent fistula
test_cases.report_text: Surveillance MRI in 11-year-old boy with Crohn's disease on adalimumab. Known transsphincteric fistula now shows radiological remission. The tract is visible only as a thin hypointense linear structure without T2 hyperintensity. No enhancement on post-contrast sequences. No perilesional inflammation. No abscess. The sphincters are intact. Rectum normal. No evidence of active perianal Crohn's disease. Clinical remission correlates with imaging findings. Continue current biologic therapy.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on pediatric biologic maintenance outcomes

test_cases.title: Pediatric moderate transsphincteric
test_cases.report_text: MRI in 13-year-old with newly diagnosed Crohn's disease presenting with perianal symptoms. A transsphincteric fistula is identified at the 7 o'clock position. The tract demonstrates moderate T2 hyperintensity consistent with active inflammation. Moderate extension into the ischioanal fossa without horseshoe component. Small perianal collection measuring 1.0 cm at the external opening. The sphincter complex shows the tract coursing through both muscles but maintains overall integrity. Rectal wall shows mild thickening. Findings indicate moderate active perianal Crohn's - recommend anti-TNF induction.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on pediatric perianal Crohn's presentation patterns

test_cases.title: Adolescent moderate perianal disease
test_cases.report_text: Pelvic MRI in 15-year-old female with known IBD and new perianal symptoms. An intersphincteric fistula is present at 5 o'clock extending into a small 1.5 cm ischioanal abscess. Moderate T2 hyperintensity within the tract and surrounding the collection. Moderate inflammatory changes in the perianal fat. Sphincter muscles intact. The rectal wall shows mild mucosal enhancement. No supralevator extension. No inflammatory mass. Findings represent moderate active perianal disease. EUA with abscess drainage recommended followed by biologic therapy optimization.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on adolescent IBD perianal presentations

test_cases.title: Pediatric complex mild-moderate
test_cases.report_text: MRI in 10-year-old boy with Crohn's disease being evaluated for increasing perianal pain. A branching fistula pattern is identified with a primary tract at 6 o'clock and a small secondary branch. Moderate T2 signal abnormality throughout. The primary tract extends through the intersphincteric space with the branch extending laterally. No discrete abscess but there is a small amount of perilesional fluid. The sphincters appear intact for age. No rectal proctitis. Overall assessment is moderate severity with complex anatomy. Pediatric surgery consultation recommended.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on pediatric complex fistula presentations

test_cases.title: Pediatric severe perianal Crohn's
test_cases.report_text: Urgent MRI in 14-year-old with known Crohn's disease presenting with severe perianal pain and fever. Extensive perianal fistulizing disease identified. A high transsphincteric fistula with marked T2 hyperintensity extends into a large 3.5 cm ischioanal abscess. Secondary tracts extend bilaterally with horseshoe configuration. The external sphincter shows significant involvement with near-complete disruption at 6 o'clock. Marked rectal wall thickening with proctitis pattern. An inflammatory phlegmon is present posteriorly. This represents severe pediatric perianal Crohn's disease requiring emergent surgical intervention. IV antibiotics initiated.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on severe pediatric perianal Crohn's presentations

test_cases.title: Adolescent severe complex fistula
test_cases.report_text: MRI in 16-year-old male with poorly controlled Crohn's disease and refractory perianal symptoms. Severe and extensive perianal fistulizing disease is present. Multiple complex interconnected tracts are identified with marked T2 hyperintensity throughout. A dominant transsphincteric tract at 5 o'clock with supralevator extension. Large presacral abscess measuring 4 x 3 cm. The sphincter complex is significantly compromised bilaterally. Marked rectal wall involvement with circumferential mucosal hyperenhancement. Inflammatory mass effect in the right ischioanal fossa. Findings indicate severe refractory disease - urgent multidisciplinary discussion regarding surgical options including possible fecal diversion.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on refractory adolescent perianal disease patterns

test_cases.title: Pediatric extensive perianal disease
test_cases.report_text: Emergency MRI in 12-year-old with acute presentation of perianal sepsis. Extensive fistulizing disease with marked inflammation. Multiple tracts identified including transsphincteric and intersphincteric components. Large bilateral ischioanal abscesses (left 2.8 cm, right 2.2 cm). Marked T2 hyperintensity throughout. Horseshoe extension across the posterior midline. The sphincter mechanism is severely compromised. Marked rectal wall inflammation with proctitis. Overall picture represents severe acute perianal Crohn's disease. Emergent EUA with drainage performed same day. IV antibiotics and biologic induction initiated.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on acute pediatric perianal sepsis presentations

test_cases.title: Small early abscess
test_cases.report_text: MRI demonstrates a small intersphincteric fistula at 3 o'clock with a tiny associated collection. The collection measures 0.9 x 0.7 cm, representing a small early abscess. Mild surrounding T2 hyperintensity limited to the immediate vicinity of the collection. The fistula tract is short and simple with no secondary extensions. No extension beyond the intersphincteric plane. Sphincter complex is intact. Rectal wall normal. Overall findings represent mild disease despite abscess presence - the abscess is small and localized. Antibiotic trial may be considered before surgical drainage.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on early/small abscess presentation patterns
test_cases.notes: Borderline Mild/Moderate - classified as Mild due to small abscess size and limited inflammation

test_cases.title: Tiny perianal collection
test_cases.report_text: MRI in patient with mild perianal symptoms. A superficial fistula tract is present at 6 o'clock with a very small associated collection measuring only 0.6 cm at the external opening. The collection shows mild rim enhancement. Minimal surrounding T2 signal abnormality. The tract itself shows only mild T2 hyperintensity. No deep extension. Both sphincters intact. Rectal wall unremarkable. Findings represent very mild disease with a tiny collection that may resolve with conservative management or simple drainage.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on minimal abscess presentations

test_cases.title: Healed simple intersphincteric
test_cases.report_text: Follow-up MRI after 6 months of biologic therapy. Previously documented simple intersphincteric fistula at 4 o'clock now shows complete healing. No active tract identified. The area of prior disease shows only a tiny focus of fibrosis without T2 hyperintensity. No enhancement. No fluid. Sphincter complex normal. No collections. The patient is asymptomatic with no drainage. Findings confirm radiological remission of the simple fistula.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on simple fistula healing patterns

test_cases.title: Resolved intersphincteric tract
test_cases.report_text: Surveillance MRI in patient with history of simple intersphincteric fistula, now on maintenance adalimumab. The previously identified fistula tract is no longer visible as an active structure. Only minimal scarring remains at the prior tract location. No T2 signal abnormality. No enhancement post-gadolinium. Sphincters intact. No perianal collections. Normal rectal wall. Clinical and imaging remission confirmed.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on adalimumab maintenance outcomes

test_cases.title: Simple type with severe inflammation
test_cases.report_text: MRI demonstrates what appears anatomically to be a simple intersphincteric fistula at 6 o'clock, but with severe inflammatory activity. The tract shows marked T2 hyperintensity with extensive surrounding soft tissue edema. A large 3 cm associated abscess is present extending inferiorly. Despite the simple intersphincteric course, the inflammation is marked with significant perilesional changes. The internal sphincter is edematous but intact. Rectal wall shows mild proctitis changes. The severity of inflammation warrants urgent intervention despite the relatively simple anatomy.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on severe inflammation in simple anatomical types

test_cases.title: Low transsphincteric - mild activity
test_cases.report_text: MRI reveals a low transsphincteric fistula at 5 o'clock. The tract courses through the lower portions of both sphincter muscles with only mild T2 hyperintensity. Minimal surrounding inflammation. No abscess or collection. The extension into the ischioanal fossa is minimal, less than 1 cm. Both sphincters show the tract but maintain their structural integrity. Rectal wall normal. Overall findings represent a transsphincteric fistula with mild disease activity - good candidate for LIFT procedure or biologic therapy.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on low transsphincteric with minimal activity

test_cases.title: Transsphincteric - partial response
test_cases.report_text: Follow-up MRI after 3 months of biologic induction. The known transsphincteric fistula at 7 o'clock shows significant improvement. T2 hyperintensity has decreased from marked to mild. The tract appears thinner. No abscess - the previously seen small collection has resolved. Minimal residual inflammation. The sphincters are intact. No rectal wall changes. Findings indicate good partial response with residual mild disease. Continue current therapy.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on biologic response patterns

test_cases.title: High transsphincteric - severe
test_cases.report_text: MRI demonstrates a high transsphincteric fistula at 6 o'clock with severe disease activity. The tract shows marked T2 hyperintensity and courses through both sphincters at a high level near the puborectalis. Severe extension into the ischioanal fossa with a 2.8 cm abscess. Marked surrounding soft tissue inflammation. The external sphincter shows significant involvement with focal disruption. Supralevator extension is present. Rectal wall thickening with enhancement. Severe transsphincteric fistula requiring surgical intervention.
test_cases.literature_basis: Based on severe high transsphincteric presentations

intentionally_unfilled.reason: Clinically contradictory - abscess by definition indicates active disease
Not applicable to fistula scoring - these are negative controls
